content: @WG-rustc-dev-guide meeting in ~ 5 minutes
I may need to leave early btw.
@WG-rustc-dev-guide let's get started ...
one of the main things I wanted to talk about is an eternal task that we had
since a long time we've been talking about reorganizing the guide
in particular check https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/196385-t-compiler.2Fwg-rustc-dev-guide/topic/Reorganizing.20the.20guide
I agree we should move more things to forge
and there was an attempt by @mark-i-m https://hackmd.io/5BnDamiMSFOO8A_S5xggYQ?both
which is probably a bit odd
in particular people have been very confused that the 'stabilizing a feature' is specifically about the compiler, because as-is the dev-guide is sort of a mishmash of the library and compiler
my intention is not to say how is the best way of organizing the guide but maybe to try to come up with ideas about how to better organize the guide

Santiago Pastorino said:

my intention is not to say how is the best way of organizing the guide but maybe to try to come up with ideas about how to better organize the guide

I think we should start by moving things to forge, and make reorganizing the guide a separate task

Joshua Nelson said:

I agree we should move more things to forge

yeah, I'd definitely move all the procedures to forge and leave in the guide only the information that is about how the compiler works
(or otherwise it will never get done)
IIRC Forge is not really aimed at people new to the project though.

Joshua Nelson said:

(or otherwise it will never get done)

definitely agree to what you have said, let's move some things otherwise we would never accomplish anything :)
I am about worried about moving to forge but that might be more of criticism of forge than of this proposal.
I think procedures probably should be moved to Forge but things like https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/feature-gates.html should stay.

Camelid said:

IIRC Forge is not really aimed at people new to the project though.

yeah, but it's understood that forge hosts procedures of all the different teams

Camelid said:

I think procedures probably should be moved to Forge but things like https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/feature-gates.html should stay.

right - the dev-guide should be specifically about the compiler
More that the dev-guide should be focused on code and Forge should be focused on procedure/communication.
Btw, is there a team that maintains Forge?

Joshua Nelson said:

Camelid said:

I think procedures probably should be moved to Forge but things like https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/feature-gates.html should stay.

right - the dev-guide should be specifically about the compiler

right, maybe we should have a section that makes things like features gate fit better
unsure tbh

Camelid said:

Btw, is there a team that maintains Forge?

I've provided PRs and people merge things but unsure if there's really a team around forge

Like I think it might be good to document some stdlib-related things (like rustc_const_stable – there have been questions about that recently) in the dev-guide. I don't know of somewhere else for them to go.
My concern about forge is that it does not appear to be well maintained

rylev said:

My concern about forge is that it does not appear to be well maintained

yeah, agreed, I've always wanted to tidy up dev-guide, forge and compiler-team repos :)
E.g. https://forge.rust-lang.org/release/triage-procedure.html :embarrassed:
At some point I would like to update the wg-triage section, but there aren't that many people on the team so it's not as important to keep the docs up to date.

Santiago Pastorino said:

rylev said:

My concern about forge is that it does not appear to be well maintained

yeah, agreed, I've always wanted to tidy up dev-guide, forge and compiler-team repos :)

but this is a bit larger to what we should be focusing on ... so ... meh :)
so, to be a little more specific, the things we were thinking of moving were things like 'how do I fork rust-lang/rust' and 'how do I use rustbot'
which are about 'how do I do things', not how the compiler works
Hmm – I feel like those should stay.

Camelid said:

At some point I would like to update the wg-triage section, but there aren't that many people on the team so it's not as important to keep the docs up to date.

for instance I've been updating prioritization wg documentation on a weekly basis :)
It's a guide to developing Rust

right now the dev-guide is two different things:

  • How does the compiler work?
  • How do I make this specific change?
and I feel like it would be easier to find information if it only did the first one
I guess I'd define the guide in a more general way, the guide is aimed for people that want to contribute to the compiler
perhaps procedure as in "how to be a team player" vs procedure "how do _I_ do this" ? first goes to forge, second stays ?
and in that sense, we want to document how the beast works and how to do certain things
Yeah, I view the dev-guide as a guide to developing the compiler, not just "how does it work"
And giving examples of how to make changes also helps with "how does it work"
hmm, ok
agreed with that @Camelid
that leaves not very much to move to forge then

By the way, are these docs up to date?

This working group aims to accomplish the following:

  • Ensure that major components of rustc are covered in rustc-dev-guide
  • Ensure that API doc coverage is at least 90%
maybe just the licenses page on Contributing?
we should remove the API thing
this group was before called learning wg :)
and "aimed" to document API stuff but that never happened

Joshua Nelson said:

that leaves not very much to more to forge then

Not really; Forge has a ton of stuff – lots of procedure for release, triage, crates.io, docs.rs, etc.
I think it's better to be focused on one thing

Camelid said:

Joshua Nelson said:

that leaves not very much to more to forge then

Not really; Forge has a ton of stuff – lots of procedure for release, triage, crates.io, docs.rs, etc.

right - I mean specifically things that are currently in the dev-guide but we should move
I think it's valuable to have one place to point people when they ask questions about contributing.
so what specific action can we take out of this meeting, regarding the organization of the guide?
E.g. when mark-i-m moved CONTRIBUTING.md to the dev-guide – that put more stuff in the same spot.
so, if we're not moving things, then we should think about re-organizing the guide. In particular I think we should combine 'building and debugging' and 'contributing' somehow
right now there is a lot of duplicate info spread out over many pages
and the 'getting started' section too
can we set as a goal to come up with a different structure for the guide for next meeting?
hmm, I feel like not much will happen if we put it off

FYI, so we don't run out of time, we have some other things on the "agenda" as well:

  • mdbook-toc (rustc-dev-guide#1014)
  • reorganize pages (rustc-dev-guide#762) [that's what we're talking about I think]
  • machine-readable dates to keep docs up-to-date (rustc-dev-guide#1018)
I would rather discuss it now, unless you have something else you want to bring up?
I guess we could collaborate on that, like if someone comes up with a first idea, we can all make suggestions and all that :)

Camelid said:

FYI, so we don't run out of time, we have some other things on the "agenda" as well:

  • mdbook-toc (#1014)
  • reorganize pages (#762) [that's what we're talking about I think]
  • machine-readable dates to keep docs up-to-date (#1018)

ah ok, let's do those first then
@Iñaki Garay wanted to talk about mdbook-toc and I would like to talk about the machine-readable dates.
Who goes first? :)

Santiago Pastorino said:

I guess we could collaborate on that, like if someone comes up with a first idea, we can all make suggestions and all that :)

are we ok with this so we move on?
is someone able to come up with something?
let's start with mark-i-m 's draft maybe: https://hackmd.io/5BnDamiMSFOO8A_S5xggYQ?both
and edit from there
:+1:
I feel that there was agreement on adding mdbook-toc and that all that remains is doing it and finding which sections would benefit from using it
ok, let's move on
Ok, so machine-readable dates then?
This is the issue: https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/issues/1018

Iñaki Garay said:

I feel that there was agreement on adding mdbook-toc and that all that remains is doing it and finding which sections would benefit from using it

do you think we need to discuss the sections for it? or are you planning to do that yourself and just need to find the time?
I'll do the first steps and when the PR is ready for review we can discuss the sections
@rylev suggested some way to make things like "As of now, ..." machine-readable so that e.g. every 6 months we could get a notification saying "check if this is up-to-date".
(Correct me if I'm wrong @rylev)
That is correct
so my concern is that people will just not add those :sweat_smile:
Well we would ask during review that people add them.
If we forget sometimes it's not like it's the end of the world.
It would just be just the status quo as of now (no pun intended)
Well, the more people do it the better the result is. Even if you only do it once you do get some utility from it
hmm, I guess so. It's certainly better than nothing

I had two ideas for implementing it:

  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/pull/1013#issuecomment-757400029
  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-dev-guide/issues/1018#issuecomment-757567773
how are you imagining the automation to work? like send emails to rustc-dev-guide@rust-lang.org or something?
Opening issues automatically?
I was imagining that we would have a GH action that would create issues
Yeah, what rylev said
I´m concerned that it will create an avalanche of issues in seven months :P
Well it could do one issue per run
Yeah, what rylev said is one possibility
So at most one issue per month
Just one issue with a bunch of checkboxes
yeah that seems fine, and it does all the dates in the one issue
We could label them as "good first issue"/"Easy" too
does anyone want to implement that automation? :P
So I guess we'd have a monthly cronjob that would check all of them
I would like to give it a shot :)
awesome! I assigned you on the issue :)
You're fast! :D
@Joshua Nelson is fast to assign, but hey it's also fast take work :heart:
I'm thinking a small Rust tool that is invoked by the GH action and produces Markdown that is put in the issue body?
Would it be an mdbook preprocessor? I'm hoping I could get away with just looking through all files that match src/**/*.md
/me likes shell scripts
but as long as it's maintainable I don't really care either way
/me does not like shell scripts
I think they're fine for some things but I'm more comfortable with Rust or Python, but I like Rust better :)
I think we have a broad idea what to do and we can work out the details later.

so that leaves

reorganize pages (#762) [that's what we're talking about I think]
like I said, I think 'getting started' is sprawled across 3 sections
Here's the correct link: rustc-dev-guide#762
ohh, yeah
I think it's fine to make the change
and add the redirects
oh sorry the issue is not related to reorganizing the sections I think - this is about how the files are laid out in the repo
but yeah, probably not the most urgent task in the world :)

Joshua Nelson said:

oh sorry the issue is not related to reorganizing the sections I think - this is about how the files are laid out in the repo

Ah, okay

Joshua Nelson said:

oh sorry the issue is not related to reorganizing the sections I think - this is about how the files are laid out in the repo

right
I don't feel strongly about this, but minor -1. I don't think having a lot of top-level files is a big deal, it's more important for things to be easy to find on the website.
I don't think anyone has complained that the guide itself is hard to change
As I’ve said I also don’t think it’s a big deal but it is an issue that’s likely to get worse

What about

We should rename the ./part-N.md intro chapters to not have N so that we can move them around.

Camelid said:

What about

We should rename the ./part-N.md intro chapters to not have N so that we can move them around.

I think that's since been fixed
hmm I guess not https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/part-2-intro.html
those I think it's worthwhile to rename just so it's less confusing
my position is that I'm also midly :+1: to make this change, but I don't think it has a huge priority (which is a nice way to say do not assign me :joy: )

For the record, it's:

src/part-2-intro.md
src/part-3-intro.md
src/part-4-intro.md
src/part-5-intro.md
No part-1-intro?
I'm willing to do the changes, but only if it's ok with the rest

Santiago Pastorino said:

my position is that I'm also midly :+1: to make this change, but I don't think it has a huge priority (which is a nice way to say do not assign me :joy: )

right, basically my position is "this is not a bad change but I don't think it's worth contributor time"
I feel it's a good use of my ocd

Iñaki Garay said:

I'm willing to do the changes, but only if it's ok with the rest

ok, if you want to tackle it go ahead :) happy to review
will prioritize accordingly
So is the plan to add more structure and then put redirects in?
the hard part is redirects, and you'll need to solve that for renaming part-n anyway

Iñaki Garay said:

I feel it's a good use of my ocd

or maybe we should prohibit you do that in order to help you :P
I think we should definitely do the part-N thing. Are you planning on doing that @Iñaki Garay?
(Of course fine to say no :)
yes, I'll do that and the redirects first, and we can then talk again
Sounds like a good plan
smaller scope means faster turnaround time
great, thanks! Assigned you on the issue
do we have something else to discuss? or are we finishing right on time? :)
well 1 minute before time :)

I do have one thing I’d like to discuss eventually. Trying to list out sections that need to be written and trying to encourage sprints for them to be written in instead of just waiting for someone to do it
But that can wait
I think organizing a time to do them together is a great idea
is this a good time for everyone? maybe we could do that at this time next week
Wednesday afternoons are in general not great for me.
FYI this time is not great for me. It’s fairly late in Europe
ok, then we should use the last couple minutes to find a different meeting time
thursdays and fridays are great for me, basically any time of day
well originally our meetings were on monday
maybe I should open a doodle where people can put their availability?
mondays are really bad for me :sweat_smile:
and are actually scheduled on the compiler calendar for mondays
If this works for everyone else we can keep it. I just thought I’d mention it
but yeah, let's try to find a better time for everyone

Joshua Nelson said:

maybe I should open a doodle where people can put their availability?

:+1:
ok, I'll do that, post it here, and people can fill it out async
I think @Joshua Nelson was proposing a special out-of-schedule meeting, right?

Iñaki Garay said:

I think Joshua Nelson was proposing a special out-of-schedule meeting, right?

let's have one more meeting with a consistent schedule first I think
organizing times is hard enough :laughing:
Sounds good to me
I'm fine either way, I'm very flexible
FYI, I added very basic info to this HackMD to summarize the meeting: https://hackmd.io/@camelid/SyDp8zK0D
I can work on gathering topics

I think we're at time. Thanks everyone for coming :) did you want to bring anything else up?

@triagebot await
Unknown Zulip user. Please add zulip-id = 232545 to your file in rust-lang/team.
boooo
@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
@Camelid do you want to take notes going forward?
I'll try for a bit, but I may drop off – basically, no guarantees :laughing:
we can take turns
sounds good - just let us know if you don't have time
And it can be shared too – someone tries to do it but other people can add to it

triagebot said:

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.

had no idea this existed, I wanted to do something like that for prioritization but we ended following a different approach
Yeah, I've seen T-release do it
@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
simulacrum just wrote it a month or two ago I think
Really? I thought it's been around for longer
does it do anything else aside from post that comment?
Not to my knowledge
I have to go now – see you all next time!
it has a lot of different commetns I think
but yeah it just posts comments
thanks everyone for coming!
this was way more productive than usual :laughing:

@WG-rustc-dev-guide please fill out the doodle when you get a chance: https://doodle.com/poll/pfccp35p42xkmgw7?utm_source=poll&utm_medium=link

(and pick at least one time other than monday :pray:)
I hope to take a look at https://hackmd.io/5BnDamiMSFOO8A_S5xggYQ?both this weekend, everyone else is free to make edits too :)

Joshua Nelson said:

@WG-rustc-dev-guide please fill out the doodle when you get a chance: https://doodle.com/poll/pfccp35p42xkmgw7?utm_source=poll&utm_medium=link

(and pick at least one time other than monday :pray:)

@WG-rustc-dev-guide thanks everyone for voting! The meeting will be at 2021-02-02T12:00:00-05:00
if someone knows how to put that on the official calendar, please do let me know
I do believe @Santiago Pastorino has access
I’m on vacations but will add that to the calendar later, for how long should the meeting be?
The doodle was for half an hour
I've created the event and scheduled every 3 weeks

Camelid said:

At some point I would like to update the wg-triage section, but there aren't that many people on the team so it's not as important to keep the docs up to date.

I finally updated the section! forge#501 :tada:
